answers.title: How to implement PIP (Picture in Picture) Mode in React Native?
answers.body:
Try re-installing react-native-pip-android and remove any changes made in android/MainActivity before.

Add this snippet in MainActivity.java to be able to listen to the changes:

import com.reactnativepipandroid.PipAndroidModule;
import android.content.res.Configuration;

@Override
public void onPictureInPictureModeChanged (boolean isInPictureInPictureMode, Configuration newConfig) {
    PipAndroidModule.pipModeChanged(isInPictureInPictureMode);
}

Build the project after the above change.

Note: Inside build.gradle you need to set the minimum sdk version to 24. PIP in android is supported from API level 24.

buildscript {
    ext {
         minSdkVersion = 24
    }
}

React Native Implementation

import PipHandler, { usePipModeListener } from 'react-native-pip-android';

export default function App() {
  // Use this boolean to show / hide ui when pip mode changes
  const inPipMode = usePipModeListener();

  if (inPipMode) {
    return (
      <View style={styles.container}>
        <Text>PIP Mode</Text>
      </View>
    );
  }

  return (
    <View style={styles.container}>
      <Text style={styles.text}>
        These text components will be hidden in pip mode
      </Text>
      <TouchableOpacity
        onPress={() => PipHandler.enterPipMode(300, 214)}
        style={styles.box}>
        <Text>Click to Enter Pip Mode</Text>
      </TouchableOpacity>
    </View>

answers.title: How to implement PIP (Picture in Picture) Mode in React Native?
answers.body:
I might have found a solution. The problem is when an Android app enters PIP, the onPause function is called. This is specified here https://developer.android.com/develop/ui/views/picture-in-picture#continuing_playback where google recommends continuing video playback in the onPause function. This is okay for Android because native views don't care about the current Activity states and can be updated even though the app is paused, or entered background state. However RN's UI update, and very importantly anything not using HeadlessJS (https://reactnative.dev/docs/headless-js-android) will just run unreliably, if they are actually running at all. The result is none of your states will update without headlessJS mode, and your UI will be a static image because it won't update. So the trick that seems to work for me is 2 folds: 1. however updating your data should be done via a headlessJs Task; and 2. trigger RN UI rendering via a method.

For #1, I just can't get the seemingly abandoned libraries (react-native-pip-android) to work. The concept is correct though and you should implement PIP just like that package. I first wanted an event emitter that notifies RN that my app entered PIP mode. It's a simple getReactInstanceManager().getCurrentReactContext().getJSModule(RCTDeviceEventEmitter.class).emit("YourEventIDHere", boolean) in the MainActivity's onPictureInPictureModeChange. However a regular event listener inside a component's useEffect won't work; I spent a day to deduce that event needs to be registered via AppRegistry.registerHeadlessTask that could be due to once onPictureInPictureModeChange is called, app is in background and non headlessTask will not execute. Then I nested this listener to a vanilla zustand store then chained that store into a useStore hook.

For #2 none of the libraries will help you because this is RN's limitation. I was going to wrap RN's rerender UI function inside a RN module method, then call it from my hook; however I could not understand how RN worked and found a more straightforward but sketchy solution - I invoke onResume immediately after PIP triggering super.onPause to resume RN to the foreground. I need to flush out my other logics first to test in release, but my UI is fully responsive in PIP under debug.

  public void onPause() {
    // If called while in PiP mode, do not pause playback
    super.onPause();
    if (Build.VERSION.SDK_INT >= Build.VERSION_CODES.N) {
      if (isInPictureInPictureMode()) {
        this.onResume(); // <--- this 
        // Continue playback
      } else {
        // Use existing playback logic for paused Activity behavior.
      }
    } else {

    }
  }

answers.title: Java conditions execution in sequence
answers.body:
Only method1() matters, once the List is not empty you don't need to check it again - and if method1() doesn't add anything to the List none of the other methods appear to run. So,

List<String> filteredList = new ArrayList<>(method1());
if (!filteredList.isEmpty()) {
    filteredList.addAll(method2());
    filteredList.addAll(method3());
    filteredList.addAll(method4());
    filteredList.addAll(method5());
    filteredList.addAll(method6());
    filteredList.addAll(method7());
}
return filteredList;

But, based on your prose you actually wanted something like

List<String> filteredList = new ArrayList<>();
if (!filteredList.addAll(method1())) {
    if (!filteredList.addAll(method2())) {
        if (!filteredList.addAll(method3())) {
            if (!filteredList.addAll(method4())) {
                if (!filteredList.addAll(method5())) {
                    if (!filteredList.addAll(method6())) {
                        filteredList.addAll(method7());
                    }
                }
            }
        }
    }
}
return filteredList;

Another option, assuming you're using Java 8+, is to iterate a List of Supplier method references. Like,

List<Supplier<Collection<String>>> func = List.of(
        this::method1, this::method2, this::method3,
        this::method4, this::method5, this::method6,
        this::method7);
List<String> filteredList = new ArrayList<>();
for (Supplier<Collection<String>> f : func) {
    if (filteredList.addAll(f.get())) {
        break;
    }
}
return filteredList;

}

return filteredList;
}

answers.title: OpenGL + Slick Loaded Textures Are Rotating
answers.body:
I have solved the problem by changing the Texture Coordinates. The new code is like this:

public static void quadPrizm(float x, float y, float z, float sx, float sy, float sz, Texture tex){
glPushMatrix();
{
    glTranslatef(x, y, z);

    tex.bind();
    glBegin(GL_QUADS);
    {
        //ROTATED (WRONG)
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);

        //THE CORRECT SIDE
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);

        //ROTATED (WRONG)
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);

        //ROTATED (WRONG)
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);

        //BOTTOM SIDE
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, -sy/2, sz/2);

        //TOP SIDE
        glTexCoord2f(0, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(0, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, -sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 4); glVertex3f(sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);
        glTexCoord2f(4, 0); glVertex3f(-sx/2, sy/2, sz/2);
        }
        glEnd();
    }
    glPopMatrix();
}

items.body_markdown:
I have an array of sprites: 

    ArrayList<Sprite> list = new ArrayList<>();

Where each sprite is added to the array list using:

    list.add(createSprite(name, x, y))

I am trying to check if the type of sprite my player (currently at x and y) is moving into is "ball" using this:

    Loader.getSpriteType("ball", x + delta_x, y + delta_y)

in my `public void move(int dir)` method.

but while the app loads, it immediately crashes declaring

     ERROR:Game.update() failure - check the game code.

There is no Game class in my project, so I am unsure how to fix this error. The getSpriteType method works well in other instances and the app works fine without it so I'm certain the error is here.

Are there any instances of this happening due to a method like this being called in a non-static method? `getSpriteType` is static.
